intro: Acaena pusilla var. suprasericascens, commonly known as the small burrweed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to New Zealand. It features small, spiny burrs that are adapted for seed dispersal by attaching to animals. The plant produces yellow flowers during the summer months, followed by the development of its characteristic bristly fruits. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and subalpine regions. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena pusilla var. suprasericascens is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is well adapted to the temperate climate and nutrient-poor soils of its native range. The variety is distinguished by its unique leaf and flower structures compared to other Acaena species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena pusilla var. suprasericascens was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. However, it has since become invasive, spreading rapidly in native ecosystems. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and can outcompete native vegetation. Its introduction has led to concerns about its impact on local biodiversity.
